meta.v: Comédia, intitulada, Os Estrangeiros. Ao iffante cardeal Dom Anrique. Feita pello Doctor Francisco de Sá de Miranda. / Comédia, intitulada, Os Vilhalpandos...
Biblioteca Nacional do Rio de Janeiro; Fac-simile provided at http://www.cet-e-quinhentos.com
Centro de Estudos de Teatro, Universidade de Lisboa
Miranda, Francisco de Sá de. Comédia dos Estrangeiros (1561); Comédia dos Vilhalpandos (1560). Online edition by José Camões. http://www.cet-e-quinhentos.com

w.f: mil quinhentos e sessenta e um

w.comment: Punctuation suggested in the CET-UL edition: "Passaram-me despois a Roma, pera onde então, por mandado da fortuna, corria tudo."
'?' signal included.
Italics included to mark direct speech (in this sentence and in the previous one).
Punctuation suggested in the CET-UL edition: "Estes homens, filha, principalmente".
Punctuation suggested in the CET-UL edition: "Como? Velha prática e sesuda."
Punctuation suggested in the CET-UL edition: "Este doudo em que anda!".
Puntuation suggested in the CET-UL edition: "E ontem a el-rei Carlos, o da cabeça grande, em Piamonte".
Italics included to mark direct speech.
Italics were included to mark direct speech.
Italics included to mark direct speech.
Italics included to mark direct speech.

The CET-UL edition suggests "tod'o nosso ganho", a contraction that is not enforced by the Old Portuguese data, were the article was not obligatory in this context (see, for instance, Leal Conselheiro's "Mas todo nosso cuydado e movimento...").
Italics included to mark a fixed expression (probably from the poem named 'Olhos verdes', from the 16th century - CET-UL edition).
Punctuation suggested in the CET-UL edition: "Pera quê? Triste de mim."
Punctuation suggested in the CET-UL edition: "...desviei-me então por outra rua. Eu lá..."

This sentence is attributed to Devorante in the original, but was included in the voice of Calídio in the CET-UL edition, a decision followed here. This is based on other versions of this text (1559; Asensio), and on its internal logic as well.
"grace freely given" - biblical reference. Italics included.

This sentence is attributed to Briobis in the original, but in the manuscripts and in the 1559 version, it is part of Devorante's turn, thus transposed accordingly in the CET-UL edition, a decision that we follow here.
"Oh Time, that devours what exists, and you, enviable old age"... "you consume everything" - Ovid, 'Metamorphoses', XV
'Where Troy once stood' (Ovid, 'Heroides', 1.1.53)
'Homeland is where one feels good.' ('Patris est ubicumque est bene' - Cicero, Tusculanae Disputationes, 5.37.108)
Italics were excluded from 'o Filósofo'.
Suggested in the CET-UL edition: "... e mais nesta idade, digo: nela me é mais necessário...".
Suggested in the CET-UL edition: "De quem, Sargenta?".
Suggested in the CET-UL edition: "Mas aqui temos Devorante. Acolhe-te Sargenta...".
Suggested in the CET-UL edition: "Que tudo se acha em ti: sisos, graças e galantarias".
Suggested in the CET-UL edition: Eis o que se diz de uma cabra morta: não diz mé".
In this and in other words of this sentence, italics were included to mark foreign expressions.
Italics included to mark direct speech.
Italics included to mark foreign expression.
Italics were included in these expressions.
'Those that go up to the sea, in ships, will see his works'. similar to an excerpt of the Psalms in the Vulgata.
Suggested in the CET-UL edition: "...pera quanto são. Quero ver o que tenho neles...".
The word 'vay' appears in the original as said by Cassiano, but corrected to appear with Calidio.
Italics included to mark direct speech.
This sentence is part of the following turn, by Calídio, in the original, but transposed in the edition as an explanation of Amente's exposition.
Grifão and Feramonte also play a part in this scene, though are not listed here.
CET-UL Edition: "...roim gente me parece, ua por ua. Não vem com ele Cassiano..."
Italics included to mark foreign language.
Suggested in the CET-UL edition: "Não pude ser bom no teu mal, perdoa-me. Ajuda-me a sofrer tanto bem,..."
CET-UL edition: "Oh, falso, como os conheces bem!"
CET-UL edition: "Que tal? Triste de mim."
Suggested in the CET-UL edition: "Disse que não queria, que toda sua vida fora...".
Suggested in the CET-UL edition: "Passo, que falamos segredo".
Punctuation suggested in the CET-UL edition: "Ele, c'os olhos cubertos d'água, alevantou-o...".
'alma', based on the Asensio Manuscript (see CET-UL Edition).
Preposition 'em' was excluded, following the Asensio manuscript and to help the expected syntactic parallelism in the coordination nem...nem (see CET-UL edition).
A paragraph break is inserted here, in some editions, such as the CET-UL.
'irão' in the Asensio manuscript and according to the preceding sentence.
comma included.
alternative punctuation: 'nam, antes a poder d'aforismos...'
alternative punctuation: 'mexidas por cifras que eles, físicos, sós entendem, e os boticairos, seus secretários.'
alternative punctuation: 'entam, deixei-me ir mais devagar, espreitando sempre a natureza e ajudando-a com bom regimento'.
alternative punctuation: '...e prazer conhecido em trajo de lágrimas.'
alternative punctuation: 'Bem te deve d'alembrar o que já falamos, antes da tua ida, sobre nossos filhos'.
Alternative punctuation: 'Danou-se-nos Cesarião, que bem o sei.'
The first 'a' is stroke out in the original.
'romanos'.
'murmurar'.
alternative punctuation: 'Quantos exemplos vês tu hoje, neste dia, por aqui ao contrário'.
In the version at the National Library of Portugal one reads 'homem' instead of 'o meu'.
alternative punctuation: 'E mais, em lugar de um pai teria ele dous.'
'recusa', 'desdém'
'defeitos'.
alternative punctuation: 'Então, ao fazer das pazes, mal polos terceiros'.
'suspendamos'.
'os pés na cova'
alternative punctuation: 'Mário está tão descansado, bocejando...'
'Sobr'isto nam se escusam contendas cada hora. Quando...' (CET-UL edition).
alternative punctuation: 'Oh, Fausta é, minha molher.'
the first 'd' is stroken and a tail was included on the last 'e'.
'enema', 'medicamento'.
Religious women, enclosed in monasteries.
Line breaks included in the edition to mark the poem.
alternative punctuation: 'Já lá vão, tarde se me ordena hoje o jantar.'
There is a bis 's' annotated over the 'f'.
Correction suggested in the CET-UL edition.
'apetites', 'desejos'.
Punctuation not present in the original (cf. CET-UL edition).
corruption of 'italiana'
'espanholas': at this time this word did not show feminine inflection.
'romana'
there is a 'c' annotated on the 't', in the original.
Allusion to the episode narrated in Virgil's 'Aeneid', VI, 124-155, where Eneas takes a bay leaf so as to protect him in journey, following Sibyl's counsel.
The 't' appears upside down in the original.
alternative punctuation: 'Antonioto, busca dinheiro e não busques Milvo, nem outrem ninguém.'
here meaning 'lhes'.
'viadores', inspectors of the royal house.
'mealheiro'.
question mark included.
the syllable 'uão' is stroken out and 'rão' is annotated beside. ('rão' modernises to 'ram'). The first 'r' is upside down.
Italics included to mark reported speech.
Punctuation included.
The correction is made by be consultation of parallel manuscripts.
'vais'.
'remear-se', later replaced by the erudite variant 'remediar-se'.
'proeza' (CET Edition).
Punctuation included at this point (cf. CET-UL edition).
the final 's' is stroke out.
alternative punctuation: 'Pede-me mais dinheiro, Fabiano amigo'.
An 's' is annotated on the 't'.
The CET edition interprets this form as the hypothetical conjugation of 'avir' in the 2nd person singular, subjunctive present, by paronymy of 'haver' (instead of 'avenhas')
The CET edition interprets this form as the hypothetical conjugation of 'avir' in the 2nd person singular, indicative present, by paronymy of 'haver'.
Punctuation included, cf. CET-UL edition.
A paragraph break is used here in the CET Edition, to mark the change to a monologue.
A paragraph break is used here in the CET Edition, to mark the change to a monologue.
In this context, 'sofrer partilha'.
smaller form of 'veem'.
There is a sentence break in the CET Edition, at this point.
A sentence break is used in the CET Edition at this point.
Punctuation included, cf. CET-UL edition.
'dobar', 'enrolar'
'de igual para igual' (CET-UL edition).
para a
para a
Punctuation included.
'escavando'
Reference to hell (Pero Botelho is how the devil is addressed in Simão Botelho's Comédia da Pastora Alfea - 2nd part) - cf. CET-UL edition.
'garras'.

João da Espera de Deus - The Wandering Jew - a Jew who taunted Jesus on the way to the Crucifixion and was then cursed to walk until the Second Coming, who was said to have a pierced hand, according to the legend.
This word is stroke out and an annotation is put beside: 'seria'.
'coalhado', 'cheio'.
Italics included to mark direct speech.
Punctuation included, cf. CET-UL edition.
'revolver'.
alternative punctuation: "... perdia, estando, tempo?"
'medras', 'aumentos'.
alternative form of 'quere-lo' (2nd. person indicative present 'queres' + clitic 'lo')
alternative form of 'quere-lo' (2nd. person indicative present 'queres' + clitic 'lo')
'quota-parte'.
'favorito', 'valido'.
'capuz'.
'burla'.
Italics included to mark an excerpt read aloud.
This whole scene has been edited by hand due to censorship. The text appears with several vertical strikethrough lines.
Dia de São Cerejo - 'nunca' (cf. Jerórimo Cardoso, CET-UL edition, fol. 4').
'inquirirem'.
Punctuation included.
Punctuation inserted.
'entabular', 'empreender'.
'alterada'.
Italics included in this sentence and in the previous one in order to mark direct speech (by the old lady).
'tratante'.
Italics marked in this utterance as a sign of direct speech.
Punctuation included.
'lhes'.
'jaboneros' ~ 'engraxates' (Port.) (vendedores de sabão).
'son'.
Italics included to mark an excerpt in foreign language.
Italics included to mark foreign language.
'sopar' in the original. cf. CET-UL edition and the Asensio manuscript.
punctuation included
ver estrelas ao meio-dia - 'molestar', 'infligir pancada'.
Question mark not present in the original.
This sentence and the previous one were censured and appear stroke out in the original, the reconstructed excerpt is due to parallel manuscripts (from the CET-UL edition).
Punctuation added.

trefo - it is said of the animal killed against the precepts of judaism, i.e. beheaded in a single stroke (cf. CET-UL edition and 'Os judeus em Portugal', vol. II, p. 305, written by Mendes dos Remédios).
Italics included to mark reported speech.
Italics included to mark direct speech.
Italics included to mark direct speech.
Italics included to mark direct speech.
Italics included to mark reported speech.
Italics included to mark reported speech.
Italics included to mark reported speech.
Italics included to mark reported speech.
Italics included to mark reported speech.
Punctuation included.
'prossegue', form of the 2nd person singular imperative, with raising of the stressed vowel.
Coined expression in the juridical circles of the time, meaning "with method, according to the law and with good reason".
'Carnaval'.
'quinta-feira da semana anterior ao Entrudo'.
Quotation marks were included in this excerpt to indicate embedded reported speech.
Italics included to mark reported speech.
"em desordem".
'capuz'.
Question mark not included in the original.
non-diphthongised form of 'veio'.
This word was included with basis on the parallel texts (manuscripts), although it is not present in the original (CET-UL edition).
'tarde piaste' (Galician idiom).
not present in the original.
'borracheira', 'disparate'.
Cf. Ato III, Cena II.
specialist in affairs related to Rome.
'litigioso'.
Punctuation not included in the original.
'a fartar'.
Italics included to mark reported speech.
'ainda'.
'embuçadas', 'disfarçadas'.
Question mark not present in the original version.
'serpente'.
'Campo dei Fiori'.
'palrador'.
'esbarrar'.
'A bag with some religious object'.
'bulir'.
'burlas'.

'tresmalhar', 'fugir'.
